results.abstract: The new collection “Jessye Norman: The Unreleased Masters” raises artistic and ethical questions.

results.title: R. Kelly Sentenced to 20 Years for Child Sex Crimes
results.abstract: The singer will serve most of the sentence in federal prison at the same time as a 30-year term for racketeering and sex trafficking.
results.byline: By Robert Chiarito and Julia Jacobs

multimedia.caption: R. Kelly in 2019. He was convicted last year of coercing minors into sexual activity and producing sex tapes involving a minor.
R. Kelly in 2019. He was convicted last year of coercing minors into sexual activity and producing sex tapes involving a minor.
R. Kelly in 2019. He was convicted last year of coercing minors into sexual activity and producing sex tapes involving a minor.

results.title: Willie Cole’s Ecological Interventions Turn Trash Into Art
results.abstract: The artist invited the community in Newark to reimagine objects that would otherwise be destined for a landfill — to look at them in a fresh, imaginative way.

multimedia.caption: Willie Cole in his artist-in-residence studio at Express Newark, where he has been assembling chandeliers made from thousands of used plastic bottles.
multimedia.copyright: Rachel Vanni for The New York Times

results.title: Tom Whitlock, Writer of ‘Top Gun’ Anthem ‘Danger Zone,’ Dies at 68
results.abstract: Mr. Whitlock’s songs, including the chart-topping “Take My Breath Away,” were central to the 1986 movie.

multimedia.caption: Giorgio Moroder, left, and Tom Whitlock posing with their Oscars at the 59th annual Academy Awards in Los Angeles on March 30, 1987. The duo received the original song honor for “Take My Breath Away,” from the movie “Top Gun.”

Giorgio Moroder, left, and Tom Whitlock posing with their Oscars at the 59th annual Academy Awards in Los Angeles on March 30, 1987. The duo received the original song honor for “Take My Breath Away,” from the movie “Top Gun.”

Giorgio Moroder, left, and Tom Whitlock posing with their Oscars at the 59th annual Academy Awards in Los Angeles on March 30, 1987. The duo received the original song honor for “Take My Breath Away,” from the movie “Top Gun.”

results.title: Christoph Waltz Has Some Thoughts
results.abstract: His title character in the new Amazon series “The Consultant” is a blend of pleasant and menacing, with some very specific ideas about running a business.

multimedia.caption: Waltz takes an analytical approach to acting, preferring not to talk too much about his “process,” or at least to have “an ironic distance” when disclosing it.
multimedia.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Waltz takes an analytical approach to acting, preferring not to talk too much about his “process,” or at least to have “an ironic distance” when disclosing it.

results.title: Review: At the Philharmonic, a Guest Challenges Common Wisdom
results.abstract: The conductor Nathalie Stutzmann surrounded a showcase for cellist Alisa Weilerstein with idiosyncratic readings of repertory staples.

multimedia.caption: The cellist Alisa Weilerstein, left, joined the New York Philharmonic — led by Nathalie Stutzmann in her debut with the orchestra — in Prokofiev’s Sinfonia Concertante.
The cellist Alisa Weilerstein, left, joined the New York Philharmonic — led by Nathalie Stutzmann in her debut with the orchestra — in Prokofiev’s Sinfonia Concertante.

results.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
results.abstract: A pairing of Clara and Robert Schumann’s piano concertos, Kurt Weill’s symphonies and Steve Reich’s string quartets are among the highlights.

results.title: Four Rising Theater Stars to Watch This Spring
results.abstract: These actors turned playwrights all excavate memories and meaning from their lives in creating these four shows, which arrive in New York in the coming months.
results.byline: By Alexis Soloski, Laura Collins-Hughes, Roslyn Sulcas and Rhoda Feng

multimedia.caption: Arinzé Kene’s “Misty” mixes spoken word, music, surreal comedy and performance to tell a tale of gentrification, racial tension and male identity.
multimedia.copyright: Tami Aftab for The New York Times

results.title: Are We Having Fun Yet? ‘Party Down’ and the Sadness of the Sitcom Revival
results.abstract: Bringing beloved comedies back from the dead is usually a bad idea. The best ones, like Starz’s cater-waiter-com, lean into the discomfort.

multimedia.caption: Most of the “Party Down” cast returned for its new revival, including, from left, Martin Starr, Megan Mullally, Ryan Hansen, Jane Lynch, Ken Marino and Adam Scott.
Most of the “Party Down” cast returned for its new revival, including, from left, Martin Starr, Megan Mullally, Ryan Hansen, Jane Lynch, Ken Marino and Adam Scott.
Most of the “Party Down” cast returned for its new revival, including, from left, Martin Starr, Megan Mullally, Ryan Hansen, Jane Lynch, Ken Marino and Adam Scott.

results.title: ‘God’s Time’ Review: Saving Her From Herself
results.abstract: Instead of making a thriller, the writer and director Daniel Antebi opts for a boho buddy comedy, with mixed results.

multimedia.caption: Liz Caribel Sierra and Dion Costelloe in “God’s Time.”
Liz Caribel Sierra and Dion Costelloe in “God’s Time.”
Liz Caribel Sierra and Dion Costelloe in “God’s Time.”

results.title: Marian Goodman Joins TriBeCa Gallery Throng
results.abstract: The 94-year-old gallerist will relocate from West 57th Street to prepare her company for the future, which includes new leadership and artist changes.

multimedia.caption: Rendering of the future home of the Marian Goodman Gallery in TriBeCa. A renovation by studioMDA will include viewing rooms, a library and archive, storage and administrative offices.
Rendering of the future home of the Marian Goodman Gallery in TriBeCa. A renovation by studioMDA will include viewing rooms, a library and archive, storage and administrative offices.
Rendering of the future home of the Marian Goodman Gallery in TriBeCa. A renovation by studioMDA will include viewing rooms, a library and archive, storage and administrative offices.

results.title: Philadelphia Museum Creates Center for African Art
results.abstract: With a gift from the trustee Ira Brind, the center will aim to advance the museum’s new Equity Agenda.

multimedia.caption: Ira Brind, second from left, is a trustee who donated money and art for the new center. He is shown with, from left, the museum officials Carlos Basualdo, Sasha Suda and Alphonso Atkins.
Ira Brind, second from left, is a trustee who donated money and art for the new center. He is shown with, from left, the museum officials Carlos Basualdo, Sasha Suda and Alphonso Atkins.
Ira Brind, second from left, is a trustee who donated money and art for the new center. He is shown with, from left, the museum officials Carlos Basualdo, Sasha Suda and Alphonso Atkins.

results.title: How Hard Is It to Paint Like Vermeer? TV Contestants Find Out.
results.abstract: Amateur and professional artists are competing to recreate some of the old master’s lost works in a Dutch reality show that coincides with a blockbuster Vermeer exhibition in Amsterdam.

multimedia.caption: Pieter Roelofs, a curator at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam and judge on “The New Vermeer,” a TV show combining highbrow culture and mass entertainment that has been a sensation in the Netherlands.
Pieter Roelofs, a curator at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam and judge on “The New Vermeer,” a TV show combining highbrow culture and mass entertainment that has been a sensation in the Netherlands.

results.title: 6 Podcasts to Help Tackle Your Climate Anxiety
results.abstract: These shows, full of passionate reporting, will leave you better informed and perhaps less prone to doom paralysis.
des_facet: How to Save a Planet (Radio Program)

results.title: Science Fiction Magazines Battle a Flood of Chatbot-Generated Stories
results.abstract: While the deluge has become a nuisance, the stories are easy to spot. The writing is “bad in spectacular ways,” one editor said.

multimedia.caption: The cover of Issue 193 of Clarkesworld magazine. The publication recently halted open submissions because of a large increase in work created by A.I. bots.
The cover of Issue 193 of Clarkesworld magazine. The publication recently halted open submissions because of a large increase in work created by A.I. bots.

results.title: Film Artists Reflect on the Movies that Left a Mark
results.abstract: For a retrospective series at the Berlin International Film Festival, directors and actors selected formative coming-of-age movies. Their choices show links between the cinematic past and present.

multimedia.caption: From left: Christina Ricci, Ashleigh Aston Moore, Gaby Hoffmann and Thora Birch in “Now and Then,” which is playing in a retrospective at the Berlin International Film Festival.
From left: Christina Ricci, Ashleigh Aston Moore, Gaby Hoffmann and Thora Birch in “Now and Then,” which is playing in a retrospective at the Berlin International Film Festival.
From left: Christina Ricci, Ashleigh Aston Moore, Gaby Hoffmann and Thora Birch in “Now and Then,” which is playing in a retrospective at the Berlin International Film Festival.

results.title: ‘Juniper’ Review: Bad Grandma
results.abstract: Starring Charlotte Rampling, this New Zealand-set drama is a portrait of intergenerational bonding with a heavy dose of cynicism.

Charlotte Rampling in “Juniper.”

results.title: ‘Bruiser’ Review: Of Fathers and Fractures
results.abstract: A teenage boy is caught between the man who raised him and a new guiding figure in this affecting study of masculinity and coming of age.

multimedia.caption: Jalyn Hall, left, as Darious and Trevante Rhodes as Porter in “Bruiser.”

results.abstract: Andie MacDowell plays a screen and stage star facing a cancer diagnosis in this film directed by Tal Granit and Sharon Maymon.

Tamsin Greig and Andie MacDowell in “My Happy Ending.”

results.title: ‘Linoleum’ Review: Rocket Plan
results.abstract: Jim Gaffigan plays a dual role as rival scientists in this mysterious yet surprisingly effective movie.

results.title: They Invited Shakespeare to the Cookout. They Got ‘Fat Ham.’
results.abstract: The playwright James Ijames and the director Saheem Ali built a “Hamlet”-inspired play, opening in April on Broadway, around their artistic friendship.

multimedia.caption: Saheem Ali, left, first directed a play by James Ijames in 2017. Ijames, right, wrote “Fat Ham” with the aim of adapting Shakespeare’s text to reflect authentic Black experiences.
multimedia.copyright: Brad Ogbonna for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Star Trek: Picard,’ Season 3, Episode 2: Another Next Generation
results.abstract: Jean-Luc Picard has not traditionally been much of a family man, but that may be changing.

multimedia.caption: Ed Speelers in “Star Trek: Picard.”
Ed Speelers in “Star Trek: Picard.”

results.title: Grief, Pain and the Lingering Impact of Trauma on Black Women’s Bodies
results.abstract: In her new novel, “An Autobiography of Skin,” Lakiesha Carr tells the stories of three contemporary Black women, each struggling with different manifestations of trauma.

results.title: 36 Hours in Miami
results.abstract: Discover the best of both new and old Miami, from a salsa club in Little Havana to a rooftop bar with striking views of downtown to Cuban American bakeries.

results.title: David Bowie, and His Personas, Will Live On at Victoria and Albert Museum
results.abstract: The London museum will house more than 80,000 items from the star’s music career at a new David Bowie Center for the Study of Performing Arts. It will open in 2025.

multimedia.caption: A detail of the striped bodysuit and red kabuki boots, designed by Kansai Yamamoto and worn by David Bowie for a tour. Many artifacts from Bowie’s career will be housed at a London museum.
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: A detail of the striped bodysuit and red kabuki boots, designed by Kansai Yamamoto and worn by David Bowie for a tour. Many artifacts from Bowie’s career will be housed at a London museum.

results.title: ‘Dancing the Twist in Bamako’ Review: Youth in Revolt
results.abstract: Robert Guédiguian’s jaunty new film places a young romance against the backdrop of post-colonial Mali in the early 1960s.

multimedia.caption: Alice Da Luz, left, as Lara and Stéphane Bak as Samba, who spends his days spreading the Marxist gospel to Mali’s peasants and landowners.
Alice Da Luz, left, as Lara and Stéphane Bak as Samba, who spends his days spreading the Marxist gospel to Mali’s peasants and landowners.

results.title: The Raincoats’ Gina Birch Goes Solo (and Still Makes the Floor Rattle)
results.abstract: At 67, a member of one of post-punk’s most influential bands is releasing “I Play My Bass Loud” and reflecting on decades of work pushing boundaries.

multimedia.caption: “If you can grow into a person that you like or are happy with, that’s pretty great,” Gina Birch said. “And I feel I’ve done quite well at that.”
multimedia.copyright: Guy Bolongaro for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “If you can grow into a person that you like or are happy with, that’s pretty great,” Gina Birch said. “And I feel I’ve done quite well at that.”

results.title: Rick Newman, Whose Comedy Club Made Careers, Dies at 81
results.abstract: Soon after he opened Catch a Rising Star in Manhattan in 1972, it became a showcase for emerging talents like Billy Crystal, Robin Williams and Pat Benatar.

multimedia.caption: Rick Newman, far right, at a party in 1982 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of his nightclub, Catch a Rising Star. With him in the back were, from left, the comedians Joe Piscopo, David Brenner and Richard Belzer and the musician Neil Giraldo. In the front were the singer Pat Benatar, whom Mr. Newman managed for many years, and Robin Williams.

Rick Newman, far right, at a party in 1982 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of his nightclub, Catch a Rising Star. With him in the back were, from left, the comedians Joe Piscopo, David Brenner and Richard Belzer and the musician Neil Giraldo. In the front were the singer Pat Benatar, whom Mr. Newman managed for many years, and Robin Williams.

Rick Newman, far right, at a party in 1982 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of his nightclub, Catch a Rising Star. With him in the back were, from left, the comedians Joe Piscopo, David Brenner and Richard Belzer and the musician Neil Giraldo. In the front were the singer Pat Benatar, whom Mr. Newman managed for many years, and Robin Williams.

results.title: ‘Murdaugh Murders’ and the Allure of Regional True Crime
results.abstract: From the Central Valley to the Lowcountry to a four-year liberal-arts college, the landscape is a character in a range of new documentary series.
des_facet: Murdaugh Murders: A Southern Scandal (TV Program)
Stolen Youth: Inside the Cult at Sarah Lawrence (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “Murdaugh Murders” on Netflix is one in a recent crop of regionally distinctive true-crime series.
“Murdaugh Murders” on Netflix is one in a recent crop of regionally distinctive true-crime series.

results.title: ‘Chocolat’: What France Knew
results.abstract: Newly restored, Claire Denis’s quasi-autobiographical “Chocolat,” a child’s-eye view of French colonialism, is austere yet vivid.

multimedia.caption: France (Cécile Ducasse), right, may be the nominal protagonist of the film, but its central character is Protée (Isaach de Bankolé).
France (Cécile Ducasse), right, may be the nominal protagonist of the film, but its central character is Protée (Isaach de Bankolé).
France (Cécile Ducasse), right, may be the nominal protagonist of the film, but its central character is Protée (Isaach de Bankolé).

results.title: When the Movies Pictured A.I., They Imagined the Wrong Disaster
results.abstract: Instead of the chilling rationality of HAL in “2001: A Space Odyssey,” we get the messy awfulness of Microsoft’s Sydney. Call it the banality of sentience.

multimedia.caption: HAL 9000, the malevolent computer in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), is terrifying precisely because he is so ordinary.
HAL 9000, the malevolent computer in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), is terrifying precisely because he is so ordinary.

results.title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Marchita’ and More
results.abstract: I'm a news editor for the Foreign desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

results.title: ‘Parade’ Producers Condemn Neo-Nazi Protest at Show About Antisemitism
results.abstract: The show’s star, Ben Platt, said the “ugly and scary” display was a reminder of why they are retelling the story of the lynching of Leo Frank, a Jewish businessman in Georgia.

multimedia.caption: Micaela Diamond and Ben Platt in last year’s production of “Parade” at New York City Center.
Micaela Diamond and Ben Platt in last year’s production of “Parade” at New York City Center.
